title: 107_hr2325
content: The "Antitrust Modernization Commission Act of 2001" establishes the Antitrust Modernization Commission to investigate issues related to antitrust laws, gather diverse perspectives, evaluate proposals, and submit a report to Congress and the President. The Antitrust Modernization Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the President, Senate majority leader, Senate minority leader, Speaker of the House, and House minority leader. Members of Congress are ineligible for appointment. Members of the Antitrust Modernization Commission are appointed for the life of the Commission, but their appointment may be terminated early if they cease to be a government officer or employee. Seven members constitute a quorum for the Commission. The Antitrust Modernization Commission requires seven members for a quorum to conduct meetings. Initial appointments must be made within 60 days of the Act's enactment. Meetings are called by the chairperson, with the first meeting to be held within 30 days of all members being appointed or funds being appropriated. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as initial appointments. Consultation is required before appointing members. The Senate, Speaker of the House, and minority leader must consult for fair representation in the Commission. SEC. 5. COMPENSATION OF THE COMMISSION. Members of the Commission are entitled to pay based on their employment status, with nongovernment employees receiving a daily rate and government employees serving without additional pay. They also receive travel expenses in accordance with regulations. Members of the Commission receive pay based on their employment status and travel expenses according to regulations. SEC. 6. STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and necessary staff without following standard appointment procedures. They can also determine their compensation without restrictions, as long as it does not exceed a certain rate of pay. The Commission's director and staff compensation cannot exceed the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants as needed. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, or a member authorized by the Commission, may hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. They can administer oaths to witnesses. The Commission can obtain information from executive agencies or courts. The Administrator of General Services will provide facilities and support services on a reimbursable basis. The Commission may request facilities and support services from executive agencies on a reimbursable basis. Expenditures and contracts can be made for necessary supplies and services with prior authorization. The Commission is allowed to use the United States mails for official purposes. The Commission is authorized to accept gifts, bequests, and devises of services or property to aid its work. Money and proceeds from sales of property received in this manner are deposited in the Treasury for disbursement upon the Commission's order. The Commission will submit a report to Congress and the President within 3 years of its first meeting, including findings, conclusions, and recommendations. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $4,000,000 is authorized for this Act.
